item.title: Monster Hunter Wilds' delectable cuisine causes cheese naan sales to surge
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/monster-hunter-wilds-delectable-cuisine-causes-cheese-naan-sales-to-surge

Praise Cheesus! We are all absolutely wild for Monster Hunter Wilds' cheese naan.

Early in Monstrer Hunter Wilds, players will get the opportunity to partake in an in-game feast which features a delicious-looking cheese naan dish. In fact, I am salivating just thinking about it, brie-lieve me. The dish in question is a generous slab of naan-like bread covered in hot, oozy cheese and yes I may have to now take a break to go and recreate it in my own kitchen.

Anyway, I am clearly not the only one to be won over by how gouda this dish looks. This scene has seemingly caused sales of actual cheese naan to be feta than ever.

A quick search of Monster Hunter Wilds Cheese Naan on social media will bring up a number of users either sharing footage from the game itself, images of their own real-world cheese naan dishes, and yes - a Tokyo restaurant saying the game really has caused its sales to surge.

For context, here's a look at Monster Hunter Wilds' in-game cheese naan scene.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

And here's Tokyo-based Nepalese restaurant Salam Namaste, which thanked Monster Hunter Wilds for boosting its cheese naan sales over the weekend.

"Cheese naan is too popular," the restaurant wrote on social media. "I had a lot of cheese with me, but it was running out, so I had no choice but to go to Inageya to get some. Thank you, Monster Hunter" (computer translated). Yes, that looked Cheddar Gorge-ous.

The game's cheese naan is certainly proving popular. One player stated they will probably manage to get "100+ hours in Monster Hunter Wilds" before they actually make it beyond the cheese naan scene. "Just rewinding the scene over and over while drool covers the controller," they wrote.

Plenty of players have now ventured into the wilds of the takeaway and restaurant world to savour cheese naan for themselves. "I have fulfilled the desire," one X user wrote with an accompanying image of naan and curry goodness (see below).

Another added: "Because of this particular cutscene in Monster Hunter Wilds, me and the princess got ourselves Cheese Naan at our local restaurant."

"That's hilarious - Monster Hunter Wilds really said, 'Let's make cheese naan the MVP of 2025! 'It's wild to think a game's gooey cheese pull could spark a culinary craze like this," another social media user wrote in response to the cheesy goodness the Monster Hunter Wilds team has blessed us with.

"Maybe Capcom should send that Nepali restaurant a thank-you note or at least a cheese care package to keep up with the hungry hunters!"

If you want to make your own Monster Hunter Wilds-inspired cheese naan, I had a quick google and have saved this recipe to try out later. Hopefully my efforts will be met with similar praise from my family and friends. They will tell me it is grate, or something along those lines, I am sure...

Anyway in the meantime, here's our guide to the best meals in Monster Hunter Wilds.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Monster Hunter Wilds has proved extremely popular for Capcom, crossing over the one million player mark on Steam on its debut.

It hasn't all been sunshine, cheese and roses for the game, however. User reviews for Monster Hunter Wilds remain "Mixed" on Steam, with the PC performance being an ongoing issue. In the words of Digital Foundry's Alex Battaglia, "lower-end graphics cards with lower VRAM allocations should avoid Monster Hunter Wilds until these issues are rectified".

item.title: Sonic Unleashed available for PC at last, thanks to fan-made port with uncapped framerate
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/sonic-unleashed-available-for-pc-at-last-thanks-to-fan-made-port-with-uncapped-framerate

Sonic Unleashed is finally available on PC thanks to a fan-made port with modern quality of life features.

Unleashed is the Sonic game with the rubbish werehog bits, but its actual Sonic levels are brilliant - their mix of sidescrolling and 3D styles formed the basis of games in the series ever since - and Sonic Generations in particular.

The game was originally released for PS3 and Xbox 360 (as well as PS2 and Wii), and now the 360 version has been unofficially ported to PC as Unleashed Recompiled.

New features include an uncapped framerate, comprehensive visual options to customise, ultrawide support, built-in achievements, and controller icons for whichever controller you use.

In short, this is now the best way to play Sonic Unleashed, although you'll need a legitimate copy of the Xbox 360 game to get it running. You can download Unleashed Recompiled on github.

Almost all the modern Sonic games are available on Steam at present, including Sonic x Shadow Generations, Sonic Frontiers, Sonic Superstars, Sonic Colors: Ultimate, Sonic Adventure 1 and 2, the Sonic racing games, and even Sonic Lost World.

Sonic Unleashed, then, is a curious omission from Sega. Should this fan-made port be a success, perhaps an official version could be released in future.

Sega's last release was Sonic x Shadow Generations, which does include an Unleashed-themed level as part of the original Sonic Generations. The new Shadow levels are fantastic.

It's unknown what's next for the series, though Sonic Team head Takashi Iizuka said Sonic Frontiers' open zone style is now the "cornerstone of future Sonic games".

In film land, though, Sonic the Hedgehog 4 has already been greenlit.

item.title: Capcom explains Monster Hunter Wilds endgame softlock workaround
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/capcom-explains-monster-hunter-wilds-endgame-softlock-workaround

Capcom has explained how to get around a perceived endgame softlock in Monster Hunter Wilds.

The main mission 5-1: Omens asks players to "Investigate the regions and raise your HR", but some players have already reached the Hunter Rank cap and have been unable to progress.

It turns out, though, the description just isn't very clear. The mission doesn't require players to raise their Hunter Rank but instead earn enough Hunter Rank Points to proceed.

Capcom's Monster Hunter Status account explained the distinction and apologised for the description not being "comprehensive on this occasion".

To get by, then, players must simply complete enough Optional Quests or Side Missions to earn enough Hunter Rank Points.

Some players have reported that if they have already reached the Hunter Rank cap when playing Main Mission 5-1: Omens, they won’t be able to complete the mission “Investigate the regions and raise your HR”.

However, even if your HR doesn’t increase, you can still complete this…

— Monster Hunter Status (@MHStatusUpdates) March 2, 2025

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Capcom's latest game in the series is seeing meteoric success, not only peaking on Steam at 1.3 million concurrent players, but propelling Steam to its highest ever concurrent player numbers.

Still, the launch hasn't been without its issues - the PC version in particular has poor performance that's been heavily criticised.

At least Capcom is speedily investigating and fixing any smaller issues that arise.
